guide.introduction: I broke a wheelbarrow handle. (which is no big deal) but this time it was a customers wheelbarrow so I had to fix it pretty nicely. Everything went smoothly until I had to lathe the part to hold. I don't have a lathe but it had to be at least half way decently round! I had no clue how to do it!
guide.introduction_rendered:
I broke a wheelbarrow handle. (which is no big deal) but this time it was a customers wheelbarrow so I had to fix it pretty nicely. Everything went smoothly until I had to lathe the part to hold. I don't have a lathe but it had to be at least half way decently round! I had no clue how to do it!

Relevant parts
  • wood to hold the piece high enough
Tools
  • screwdriver, variable speed angle grinder.

parts.text: wood to hold the piece high enough

lines.text: Secure your work really well. I used a screw through the piece at each end (these rotate with the piece  and 2 screws at one end 3 at the other to keep it   from hopping off the "lathe"

lines.text: The angle grinder is rested on the bench for ease of use

guide.summary: This is a rough "alternative"  lathe that is easy to set up and use.  The angle grinder both cuts and turns the project so it is simpler than a real lathe.
guide.title: Use a variable speed angle grinder as a lathe!
